reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed fever and cough without obvious triggers on January 30, 2021, and went to a local hospital. After anti-infective treatment, the symptoms were not relieved, and routine blood tests showed that the white blood cell count continued to increase and the hemoglobin decreased. Further examination revealed that chest CT showed infectious lesions in the left lower lung, bone marrow aspiration showed active proliferation, an increased proportion of blast cells, and flow cytometry detected abnormal myeloid phenotype immature cells.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Blood routine:
  - White blood cell count: 47.51x10^9/L (increased)
  - Hemoglobin: 75g/L (decreased)
  - Platelet count: 188x10^9/L
- Inflammation markers:
  - C-reactive protein: 101.5mg/L (increased)
- Coagulation:
  - Procalcitonin activity: 65% (decreased)
  - Prothrombin time: 14.7s (extended)
  - International Normalized Ratio: 574mg/dL (elevated)
  - Fibrin degradation products: 17.6ug/ml (increased)
- Virus screening: negative
- Biochemical tests:
  - Electrolytes, liver and kidney function: no obvious abnormalities
- Film degree exam:
  - Chest CT: Infectious lesions in the left lower lung
  - Cardiac ultrasound: left ventricular ejection fraction 61.18%, no obvious abnormalities in intracardiac structure and blood flow
  - Abdominal ultrasound: The spleen is enlarged and can reach 1.2cm under the ribs
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Acute myeloid leukemia (high-risk type)
reference_diagnosis.basis: The patient was a young male with acute onset. Blood routine showed an increase in white blood cells. Bone marrow puncture showed that the proportion of blast cells was 37.5%. Flow cytometry detected abnormal myeloid phenotype blast cells occupying 15.58% of nucleated cells and expressing CD34st, CD117st, CD38, etc. , some cells express CD36, HLADR, CD81, but do not express CD33, CD7, CD10, etc., which meet the diagnostic criteria for acute myeloid leukemia.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After the patient was admitted to hospital, he was given anti-infective treatment and his fever was relieved, but the blood routine showed that the white blood cell count was still elevated. Bone marrow genetic testing showed increased expression of WT1 and EVI1, and negative FLT3-TD and NPM1 mutations. The bone marrow morphology showed active proliferation and the proportion of blasts was 50%. NGS testing revealed FLT3-TKD and TP53 germline mutations. The patient received HAA regimen chemotherapy and developed gastrointestinal reactions during chemotherapy, which improved after symptomatic treatment. Bone marrow flow cytometry showed that BCL-2 positive cells accounted for 23.05%. Bone marrow chromosomal testing revealed abnormalities. The patient developed a pulmonary infection during the bone marrow suppression period. After antibacterial treatment, the infection improved and his blood count returned to normal.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Fever (38.5°C to 39°C) for more than 10 days
(2) Persistent cough with yellowish mucus
(3) Chest pain and shortness of breath, especially when coughing or exerting oneself
(4) Headache and body aches
(5) Fatigue and weakness
(6) Easy bruising

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Chest CT: Infectious lesions in the left lower lung
(2) Bone marrow aspiration: Active proliferation and an increased proportion of blast cells
(3) Flow cytometry: Abnormal myeloid phenotype immature cells
(4) Complete blood count (CBC): Elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin, and low platelet count
(5) Blood chemistry test: Liver dysfunction
(6) Repeat chest CT: Increased size and number of lesions in the left lower lung, and new lesions in the right lung

#Diagnosis#
Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Bone marrow aspiration and flow cytometry results indicating abnormal cell proliferation and blast cells
(2) CBC results showing elevated white blood cell count, low hemoglobin, and low platelet count
(3) Chest CT and repeat chest CT results showing progressive lung lesions
(4) Liver dysfunction indicated by blood chemistry test

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Hospitalization for further evaluation and treatment
(2) Supportive care to manage symptoms and prevent complications
(3) Chemotherapy to kill cancer cells in the bone marrow
(4) Possible bone marrow transplant
(5) Consultation with a hematologist and oncologist to determine the best course of treatment

reference_diagnosis.symptom: Six years ago, the patient had dull pain in the right hypochondrium, accompanied by swelling and discomfort in the shoulder and back. He was diagnosed with hepatitis B, and abdominal ultrasound showed fatty liver. After antiviral treatment with entecavir, the symptoms were relieved and he has been taking the medicine ever since. One month ago, the discomfort in the right hypochondrium worsened, and he lost about ten pounds. Ultrasound at another hospital found a medium-high echo mass in the liver, which was considered a liver mass. He came to our hospital for further diagnosis and treatment.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Imaging examination
- Abdominal ultrasound: intrahepatic medium-high echo mass.
- Upper abdominal enhanced MRI: 5.5*6cm space-occupying lesion in the left lobe of the liver, hepatocellular carcinoma is considered; mild cirrhosis; multiple small and slightly enlarged lymph nodes in the hepatogastric space and retroperitoneum.
- Laboratory examination
- Liver function: Alanine aminotransferase 61U/L increased, aspartate aminotransferase 42U/L increased, alkaline phosphatase 98U/L normal, glutamyl transpeptidase 52U/L normal, total bilirubin 8.9umol/L normal, albumin 48.5g/L normal, total cholesterol 3.49mmol/L normal, triglyceride 1.17mmol/L normal, high-density lipoprotein 0.81mmol/L decreased.
- Tumor markers: AFP 5.46ug/L normal, carcinoembryonic antigen, carbohydrate antigen CA199 normal.
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Hepatocellular carcinoma stage T1bN0M0IB, cirrhosis
reference_diagnosis.basis:
① He has a history of hepatitis B for six years and has been taking entecavir for a long time.
② I have recently experienced discomfort in my right flank and lost weight.
③ Ultrasound and magnetic resonance examination showed space-occupying lesions in the left lobe of the liver, suggesting hepatocellular carcinoma and cirrhosis.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: The patient had a history of hepatitis B for six years, and recently had discomfort in the right ribs and weight loss. After admission, a detailed examination was conducted. He was diagnosed with liver cancer and cirrhosis. Imaging showed no distant metastasis and was suitable for surgical treatment. Relevant examinations and preparations were performed before surgery, including hepatic artery chemotherapy drug perfusion embolization. Fever and abnormal liver function occurred after surgery, which improved after anti-infection and liver protection treatment. Two weeks after surgery, the tumor shrank to 5*4cm, and laparoscopic left lateral hepatectomy was performed. Postoperative pathology confirmed hepatocellular carcinoma, moderately differentiated, with a tumor size of 4.5*5.0*2.8cm, and no residual liver capsule or stump cancer tissue. The postoperative evaluation was T1bN0M0IB stage. Anti-infection, liver protection, and stomach protection treatments were given after surgery. After discharge, continue to take entecavir and have regular follow-up.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient has developed symptoms such as fatigue, palpitation, and dizziness since December 27, 2020, accompanied by tinnitus. The symptoms worsened after activity. The physical examination at the unit revealed abnormal blood routine, but no attention was paid to it. Subsequently, the symptoms gradually worsened, accompanied by gum swelling and pain, and low-grade fever. Routine blood tests showed a decrease in white blood cells and hemoglobin, and bone marrow examination showed acute myeloid leukemia. After chemotherapy, the symptoms improved and the blood count recovered. Repeat bone marrow examination showed disease remission.

Bone marrow examination showed that immature monocytes accounted for 92.5%. Bone marrow flow cytometry showed that abnormal myeloid immature cells accounted for 94.50%. Chromosome karyotype analysis showed complex The karyotype is consistent with the diagnosis of acute myeloid leukemia (M5).
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient underwent lumbar puncture and intrathecal injection for preventive treatment, and no abnormalities were found in cerebrospinal fluid examination. Then the medium-dose Ara-C regimen chemotherapy was started. The treatment process went smoothly, no obvious adverse reactions were seen, and the patient was discharged after his vital signs stabilized.

Emergency ultrasound examination revealed gallbladder stones and acute cholecystitis was considered. He was admitted to the hospital after anti-infection and rehydration treatment. Since the onset of the disease, he has been in good mental state, sleeping normally, eating less, having no abnormalities in urination and defecation, and having no significant changes in weight.

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Acute cholecystitis, gallbladder stones, dyslipidemia
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Abdominal pain for 4 days, upper abdominal cramping and then spread to the whole abdomen.
2. Past history of gallbladder stones.
3. Auxiliary examinations showed elevated C-reactive protein, mildly elevated amylase and lipase, abnormal blood lipids, and ultrasound and CT showed gallstones accompanied by cholecystitis.
reference_diagnosis.treatment:
1. After thorough examination after admission, CRP was elevated, transaminases and bilirubin were normal, and ultrasound and CT showed gallstones accompanied by cholecystitis.
2. For treatment, a liquid diet, pantoprazole 20 mg once every two days for acid suppression, piperacillin-tazobactam 4.5 g every 12 hours for intravenous anti-infection, and fluid rehydration were given for 5 days.
3. The patient's abdominal pain is relieved and there is no nausea or vomiting. It is recommended that he and hepatobiliary surgery be further diagnosed and treated after discharge to evaluate the indications for cholecystectomy.

Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Abdominal pain for 4 days, starting as epigastric cramping after eating pineapple and fried meat, and then spreading to the entire abdomen

(4) Dull ache, sometimes sharp and stabbing

#Auxiliary Examinations#

(2) Blood tests: slightly elevated liver function tests, mild elevation in white blood cell count, and normal pancreatic enzymes

#Diagnosis#
Acute cholecystitis

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Ultrasound findings of thickened gallbladder wall and pericholecystic fluid, indicating inflammation of the gallbladder
(2) Blood test results showing elevated liver function tests and mild elevation in white blood cell count, consistent with inflammation and infection
(3) Patient's symptoms of abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and dizziness, consistent with acute cholecystitis

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Admit the patient to the hospital for further treatment and observation
(2) Start antibiotics to treat the infection
(3) Perform a laparoscopic cholecystectomy to remove the gallbladder
(4) Manage pain and symptoms with medication during the recovery process
(5) Follow a low-fat diet for a few weeks after the surgery

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Lethargy for about half a month, worsened over the past two days
(2) Diarrhea and vomiting
(3) Abdominal pain
(4) Poor appetite
(5) Nausea
(6) Fatigue and weakness
(7) Decreased urine output and darker urine color
(8) Muscle aches
(9) Swelling in legs and feet

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Complete Blood Count (CBC): elevated white blood cell count
(2) Blood Chemistry: electrolyte imbalance, low sodium and potassium levels, elevated creatinine and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) levels
(3) Urinalysis: presence of white blood cells and bacteria in urine, indicating urinary tract infection (UTI)

#Diagnosis#
Dehydration, electrolyte imbalance, kidney dysfunction, and urinary tract infection (UTI)

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Patient's symptoms, including lethargy, diarrhea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and decreased urine output
(2) Results of auxiliary examinations, including CBC, blood chemistry, and urinalysis
(3) Medical history, including recent herpes zoster infection

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Antibiotics to treat UTI
(2) Medication to correct electrolyte imbalance
(3) Intravenous fluids to treat dehydration
(4) Rest and hydration to help with recovery
(5) Monitoring of kidney function and adjustment of treatment plan as needed
(6) Follow-up appointments to check on progress and adjust treatment plan as needed

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed chest tightness, shortness of breath, and occasional palpitations after exerting himself 6 months ago, but the symptoms resolved spontaneously. Symptoms have worsened in the past week, accompanied by fatigue and decreased activity tolerance. There was no syncope, nausea, vomiting, or precordial pain. The electrocardiogram from another hospital showed atrial fibrillation, and the ejection fraction on cardiac color Doppler ultrasound was 35%. The patient was given coronary enlargement, anti-platelet, lipid-lowering, and anti-heart failure treatments in the outpatient clinic. However, the symptoms persisted, so he was admitted to the hospital. There was no fever, cough, sputum production, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea or lower limb edema. He can eat well, has normal bowel movements, and has no significant change in weight.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- blood test:
  -NT-ProBNP: 404.20 pg/mL
- Echocardiography:
  - Left atrial diameter: 58×50 mm
  - Inner diameter of right atrium: 51×45 mm
  - Left ventricular end diastolic diameter: 58 mm
  - Mitral and tricuspid regurgitation: trace-mild
  - Aortic valve degeneration
  - Reduced left ventricular diastolic function
  - Decreased overall left ventricular systolic function (ejection fraction EF: 34%)
- Holter ECG:
  - Ectopic rhythm
  - Atrial fibrillation with fast ventricular rate (average heart rate 105 beats/min)
  - T wave changes
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Alcoholic cardiomyopathy and cardiac insufficiency (cardiac function class II)
2. Cardiac arrhythmia atrial fibrillation
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. The patient has a history of smoking and drinking, chest tightness, shortness of breath, and cardiac color ultrasound ejection fraction of 35%.
2. Physical examination showed irregular heartbeat, varying heart sounds, and electrocardiogram showed atrial fibrillation.
3. The patient has risk factors for coronary heart disease and has chest tightness and shortness of breath after activity. Coronary heart disease cannot be ruled out.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient was given treatment to reduce the preload and postload of the heart, including recombinant human natriuretic peptide, furosemide, spironolactone, sacubitril valsartan, dapagliflozin, metoprolol succinate, aspirin, clopidogrel, and rivaroxaban. Coronary CTA showed no stenosis. Considering alcoholic cardiomyopathy, dual anti-antibody was stopped, and anti-heart failure treatment was continued. Before discharge, EF increased to 54%, and the diagnosis was revised to alcoholic cardiomyopathy.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Intermittent chest tightness and shortness of breath for 6 months, worsening over the past week
(2) Palpitations
(3) Fatigue and decreased activity tolerance
(4) Shortness of breath even with simple tasks

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) ECG: changes in ST segment indicating ischemia or strain on the heart
(2) Chest X-ray: normal
(3) Blood tests: elevated liver enzymes, elevated cardiac biomarkers (troponin), and elevated BNP level

#Diagnosis#
Heart failure with atrial fibrillation, possible coronary artery disease, and liver disease related to long-term alcohol consumption

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Symptoms of chest tightness, shortness of breath, and fatigue, along with palpitations
(2) ECG changes indicating ischemia or strain on the heart
(3) Elevated cardiac biomarkers and BNP level suggesting cardiac damage or strain
(4) Elevated liver enzymes indicating liver disease related to alcohol consumption

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Adjust medications to manage atrial fibrillation and heart failure symptoms
(2) Schedule echocardiogram and cardiac catheterization to further evaluate heart function and coronary arteries
(3) Recommend reducing or stopping alcohol consumption to help reduce strain on heart and liver
(4) Consider lifestyle changes, such as increasing physical activity and improving diet, to help manage symptoms and improve overall health

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient had palpitations 20 years ago without clear triggers, which were paroxysmal and resolved spontaneously within a few minutes. He went to the hospital and the electrocardiogram showed supraventricular tachycardia, but no special treatment was given. Symptoms recurred and she did not see a doctor again. Today, the palpitations worsened, accompanied by chest tightness without relief. There was no chest pain, headache, dizziness, nausea and vomiting, slurred speech, or unsteady walking. The emergency electrocardiogram showed supraventricular tachycardia, which converted to sinus rhythm after cardioversion with propafenone. His energy, appetite, and sleep were poor, his stool and urine were normal, and there was no change in his weight.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- EKG
  - First time: supraventricular tachycardia (HR196 beats/min)
  - Review: sinus rhythm, ST segment depression
- Chest CT
  - The texture of both lungs is enhanced, it is recommended to combine clinical and periodic review
- Blood routine
  - White blood cells 12.74*10^9/L
  - Potassium ion 5.23mmol/L
  - Myoglobin 148ng/ml
  - B-type natriuretic peptide precursor 303pg/ml
- Liver and kidney function, coagulation function
  - No obvious abnormality found
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Arrhythmias: paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia, cardiac function class II (NYHA), hypertension class 1, high risk group.
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Elderly female, hypertension, smoking history, and risk factors for atherosclerosis.
2. Admission due to worsening palpitations and chest tightness.
3. Electrocardiogram showed supraventricular tachycardia, chest CT showed enhanced texture in both lungs, blood routine showed elevated white blood cells, and potassium ions, myoglobin, and B-type natriuretic peptide precursor were abnormal.
4. Physical examination: blood pressure 141/72mmHg, heart rate 76 beats/min, regular rhythm, no pathological murmur.
5. Heart function class II (NYHA): slightly short of breath after general activities.
6. Hypertension grade 1, very high risk group: blood pressure up to 160/100mmHg, no medication, blood pressure not regularly monitored.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, anti-platelet aggregation, lipid-lowering, plaque stabilization, coronary expansion, blood pressure lowering, ventricular remodeling inhibition, and ventricular rate slowing treatments were given. CAG examination excludes coronary heart disease. After intracardiac electrophysiological examination + cardiac radiofrequency ablation, his condition was stable and he was discharged.

(1) Electrocardiogram (ECG): rapid heart rate, irregular rhythm, and premature ventricular contractions (PVCs)

Possible myocardial infarction (heart attack) or hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Patient's symptoms of palpitations, chest tightness, and fatigue
(2) ECG results showing rapid heart rate, irregular rhythm, and PVCs
(3) High levels of troponin in blood tests, indicating possible heart damage

(2) Medications to manage symptoms and reduce risk of further heart damage, such as beta blockers, ACE inhibitors, antiplatelet medications, and statins
(3) Possible implantation of a pacemaker or defibrillator to regulate heart rhythm, depending on test results and diagnosis.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient reported that he began to have pain in the joints of his limbs, especially his knees and shoulder joints, 1 week ago. He was accompanied by fatigue, increased stool frequency, yellow stools and rotten texture. During this period, there were no symptoms such as cough, sputum, chest tightness and chest pain, but there was low-grade fever. No frequency of urination, urgency of urination or painful urination. Liver function tests at the local hospital were abnormal, ALT and AST were elevated, and albumin was reduced. Oral medication was tried but the effect was not good. The patient's spirit and sleep were normal, his weight change was unknown, and he had no history of exposure to COVID-19. After admission, the nucleic acid screening test for COVID-19 was negative.

  - ALT: 196.81 U/L
  - AST: 239.46 U/L
  - Albumin: 34.46 g/L

  - Chest X-ray: No abnormality
  - CT: liver cirrhosis, left renal cyst, prostate calcification
- Other checks
  - Coagulation function: prothrombin time 14.5 seconds, thrombin time 17.2 seconds
  - Liver function: alanine aminotransferase 188.00 U/L, aspartate aminotransferase 228.00 U/L, total bilirubin 36.66 μmol/L, direct bilirubin 12.87 μmol/L, indirect bilirubin 23.79 μmol/L, total bile acid 24.50 μmol/L, adenosine deaminase 31.80 U/L
  - Immunological examination: rheumatoid factor 13.70 IU/ml, anti-streptolysin O 14.70 IU/ml, anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody 7.90 U/ml

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Cirrhosis (unknown cause)
2. Hypoproteinemia
reference_diagnosis.basis:

2. Blood biochemical tests showed elevated ALT and AST, and decreased albumin.
3. Imaging examination suggests liver cirrhosis.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient underwent comprehensive examination and treatment, including liver function protection, anti-inflammation, and albumin supplementation. After 8 days of treatment, the patient's symptoms were relieved.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Recurrent limb joint pain, fatigue, and increased stool frequency for about a week
(2) Swelling, warmth, and morning stiffness in the knees and shoulders
(3) Low-grade fever, nausea, and yellow stools with a rotten texture
(4) Chronic joint pain in the limbs for more than half a year

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Abnormal liver function test results
(2) Elevated inflammatory markers (CRP and ESR)
(3) Positive results for anti-nuclear antibodies (ANA) and rheumatoid factor (RF)
(4) Ultrasound showing an enlarged liver and inflammation in the liver and gallbladder

#Diagnosis#
Autoimmune hepatitis with rheumatoid arthritis

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Abnormal liver function test results and ultrasound findings indicating liver inflammation
(2) Elevated inflammatory markers and positive autoimmune panels (ANA and RF) suggesting an autoimmune disorder
(3) Presence of chronic joint pain and morning stiffness consistent with rheumatoid arthritis
(4) Exclusion of other potential causes of symptoms through auxiliary examinations

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Referral to a rheumatologist for further evaluation and management of rheumatoid arthritis
(2) Immunosuppressive therapy to reduce inflammation and suppress the immune system
(3) Medications to manage symptoms, such as pain relief and anti-nausea medications
(4) Lifestyle modifications, including dietary changes and stress management, to support overall health and well-being

#Symptoms#
(1) Dizziness and feeling like passing out
(2) Syncope (fainting) episodes, 3 times in the past 5 days
(3) Weakness and unsteadiness during dizziness episodes
(4) No specific triggers or warning signs for symptoms

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) ECG: Prolonged QT interval, nonspecific ST-T wave changes
(2) 24-hour Holter monitor: Ventricular ectopy (premature heartbeats)
(3) Echocardiogram: Mild left ventricular hypertrophy, normal left ventricular function
(4) Complete Blood Count (CBC): Normal
(5) Basic Metabolic Panel (BMP): Normal, except for slightly low potassium level
(6) Electrolyte level tests: Low potassium (3.5 mmol/L) and magnesium (1.8 mg/dL) levels

#Diagnosis#
Long QT syndrome with ventricular ectopy, likely caused by electrolyte imbalance (hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia)

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Prolonged QT interval on ECG, consistent with long QT syndrome
(2) Ventricular ectopy on 24-hour Holter monitor, supporting cardiac arrhythmia diagnosis
(3) Low potassium and magnesium levels, contributing to cardiac arrhythmia and prolonged QT interval
(4) Mild left ventricular hypertrophy on echocardiogram, consistent with history of hypertension

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Potassium and magnesium supplements to correct electrolyte imbalances
(2) Medication to regulate heart rhythm and reduce ventricular ectopy
(3) Referral to cardiologist for further evaluation and management of heart rhythm and function
(4) Follow-up appointment in 1 week to reassess symptoms and adjust treatment plan as needed

reference_diagnosis.treatment: A comprehensive examination was performed after admission, and the laboratory test results were as above. After a week of active treatment, the patient's symptoms improved and he was discharged.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient was diagnosed with atrial fibrillation 3 years ago and underwent cardiac electrophysiological examination and radiofrequency ablation. Atrial flutter occurred 1 month after surgery, and sinus rhythm was restored after electroconversion treatment. One week ago, he developed a rapid heartbeat. The emergency electrocardiogram showed atrial flutter with a heart rate of 142 beats/min. After treatment with amiodarone, the heart rate dropped to 104 beats/min. The follow-up ECG showed a heart rate of 140 beats/min, and he is currently hospitalized for further treatment. There was no blurred vision, dizziness and headache, fever and chills, cough and phlegm, chest tightness and shortness of breath, nausea and vomiting, abdominal pain and diarrhea, frequent urination, urgent urination and painful urination, edema of both lower limbs, or nighttime awakening. His diet and sleep were normal, his mental and physical strength was good, his bowel movements were normal, and there was no significant change in his weight. I have a history of hypertension for 3 and a half years, with the highest blood pressure recorded at 160/90mmHg. I am currently taking enalapril maleate tablets to control my blood pressure at 110-120/90mmHg.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- EKG
  - Electrocardiogram on admission: atrial fibrillation, heart rate 146 beats/min.
- Film degree exam
  - Plain CT scan of the lungs: atelectasis in the middle lobe of the right lung, localized emphysema in both lungs, bullae in the upper and middle lobes of the right lung, small nodules in the right lung, tiny nodules in the left lung, chronic inflammation in the upper lobe of the left lung, Old lesions in both lungs, tracheal sputum plugs, and atherosclerosis of the aorta and coronary arteries.
- Echocardiography
  - Transesophageal three-dimensional echocardiography: There is no thrombus in the left and right atrium and atrial appendage, and the function of the left atrial appendage is reduced.
  - Transthoracic three-dimensional cardiac ultrasound: Bi-atrial enlargement, left ventricular myocardial hypertrophy, mild bicuspid and tricuspid valve regurgitation, aortic valve degeneration, reduced left ventricular diastolic function, and normal left ventricular overall systolic function.
- Laboratory tests
  -NT-ProBNP: 1419.00 pg/mL
  - HDL-C: 0.81 mmol/L
  - apoA-1: 0.99 g/L
  - The rest of the tests showed no abnormalities.
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Arrhythmia: atrial fibrillation, status after cardiac electrophysiological examination and radiofrequency ablation, repeat cardiac electrophysiological examination and radiofrequency ablation, and postoperative left atrial appendage occlusion.
reference_diagnosis.basis: Physical examination revealed arrhythmia, and the auxiliary examination and admission electrocardiogram showed atrial fibrillation with a heart rate of 146 beats/min.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: The patient underwent lung CT scan, transesophageal and transthoracic cardiac ultrasound examination, which revealed atelectasis in the middle lobe of the right lung and localized emphysema in both lungs. Cardiac ultrasound showed biatrial enlargement, left ventricular myocardial hypertrophy, mild valvular regurgitation, and reduced left ventricular diastolic function. Laboratory tests showed elevated NT-ProBNP. The patient's stroke score and bleeding score were both high, and he did not agree with long-term oral anticoagulant therapy. Therefore, it was recommended to undergo radiofrequency ablation of atrial fibrillation combined with left atrial appendage closure surgery. After the operation, the heart rate returned to sinus, anticoagulation and antiplatelet therapy was continued, and the patient's condition improved and she was discharged.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Cough, sputum production, and shortness of breath for more than 4 months
(2) Symptoms worsen with physical activity and improve with rest
(3) Morning and evening symptoms are worse due to cold air
(4) Fatigue and decreased endurance

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Chest X-ray: opacities in the lower lobes of the lungs
(2) Spirometry test: reduced FEV1, indicating airway obstruction
(3) Complete Blood Count (CBC): mild elevation in white blood cell count, indicating low-grade infection or inflammation
(4) Sputum culture: presence of Gram-negative bacteria

#Diagnosis#
Chronic bronchitis or bronchiectasis with bacterial infection

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Persistent cough, sputum production, and shortness of breath for more than 4 months
(2) Abnormal chest X-ray and spirometry test results
(3) Presence of Gram-negative bacteria in sputum culture
(4) Mild elevation in white blood cell count on CBC

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Antibiotics to clear up the bacterial infection
(2) Bronchodilator to help open up airways and make breathing easier
(3) Mucolytic agent to help thin out mucus in the lungs and make it easier to cough up
(4) Lifestyle changes, including quitting smoking, avoiding exposure to pollutants, using an air purifier, and starting gentle exercises to improve lung function

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient began to experience lumbosacral pain 9 months ago. The pain worsened when resting and she felt pain when sitting for a long time or sleeping. The symptoms were relieved after activity. Lameness occurs when the pain is severe, accompanied by morning stiffness for more than half an hour. Symptoms such as aniridocyclitis, urinary tract infection, diarrhea, dry mouth, dry eyes, fever, rash, mouth ulcers, or photosensitivity. Symptoms improved after taking celecoxib, but the pain recurred. The patient came to the hospital for further diagnosis and treatment. Before admission, his energy, appetite, and sleep were normal, his urinary and fecal functions were normal, and his weight did not change significantly.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- blood test
  - Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR): 26mm/h (↑)
  - C-reactive protein (CRP): 21.4mg/L (↑)
  - Routine blood test, four items of coagulation, kidney function, four items before blood transfusion, complete rheumatism test, ANCA, liver function, blood lipids, three items of thyroid function, cardiac enzymes, electrolytes, D-dimer, glycosylated hemoglobin, PPD skin test: Not available See obvious abnormalities
- Film degree exam
  - Spinal joint MRI
    - Signal changes in bilateral sacroiliac joints, consider ankylosing spondylitis
    - C5/6 disc herniation
    - No obvious abnormalities in thoracolumbar spine
  - Lung HRCT
    - There are a few fibroproliferative lesions in both lungs, and some small nodules are classified as LU-RADS 2. Annual review is recommended.
    - Emphysema
- Other checks
  - Cardiac color ultrasound, abdominal B-ultrasound: no obvious abnormalities
  - Human leukocyte antigen B27 assay (HLA-B27): Positive (155)
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Ankylosing spondylitis
2. Lumbar disc herniation
3. Small pulmonary nodules
4. Emphysema
reference_diagnosis.basis: The patient was a young male who complained of recurring lumbosacral pain for 9 months. The pain worsened during rest and was relieved after activity. He was accompanied by morning stiffness for more than half an hour. He had no history of heavy physical labor. Symptoms were temporarily relieved after treatment with celecoxib but relapsed. Consider the possibility of ankylosing spondylitis and do not rule out lumbar disc herniation.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, relevant examinations were completed. ESR and CRP were elevated, and HLA-B27 was positive. Spinal joint MRI showed signal changes in bilateral sacroiliac joints, C5/6 intervertebral disc herniation, and lung HRCT showed emphysema and small nodules. The diagnosis was ankylosing spondylitis, lumbar disc herniation, pulmonary nodules, and emphysema. Treatment uses adalimumab 40 mg subcutaneously and celecoxib taken orally to relieve pain. After treatment, the symptoms improved, there was no lumbosacral joint pain, and there was no restriction of activity. He was discharged from the hospital and recommended to follow up for follow-up in 2 weeks and continue monoclonal antibody treatment.

(6) Pain relieved by celecoxib

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) X-ray: degenerative disc disease, osteophyte formation
(2) MRI: degenerated discs, bulging and herniation, facet joint hypertrophy, ligamentum flavum hypertrophy

#Diagnosis#
Degenerative disc disease, facet joint syndrome, and ligamentum flavum hypertrophy

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Patient's symptoms and medical history
(2) Physical examination findings (tenderness, limited range of motion, stiffness)
(3) Imaging results (X-ray and MRI)

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Physical therapy to improve flexibility, strength, and range of motion
(2) Pain management with medications and injections (epidural steroid injections, facet joint injections)
(3) Lifestyle modifications (regular stretching, improved posture, weight loss if necessary)
(4) Follow-up appointment in 4-6 weeks to reassess symptoms and adjust treatment plan as needed

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: myasthenia gravis
reference_diagnosis.basis: The patient presented with diplopia, drooping of the left eye and face, fluctuating symptoms, positive fatigue test, and positive myasthenia gravis antibody spectrum. Myasthenia gravis was considered.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, chest CT, cranial MRI, and SWI were performed, and no thymic hyperplasia or brainstem lesions were found. The symptoms improved and the patient was discharged from hospital.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Diplopia (double vision) for about a year, fluctuating in severity
(2) Left eye and face drooping for about a month, gradual onset
(3) Head discomfort
(4) Blurred vision, especially when looking to the sides or upwards
(5) Eye fatigue, especially when reading or watching TV

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) MRI scan of the brain: small lesion in the cavernous sinus, compressing the third cranial nerve
(2) Blood work: elevated levels of inflammatory markers

#Diagnosis#
Tolosa-Hunt syndrome

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Symptoms of diplopia, eye drooping, and head discomfort consistent with compression of the third cranial nerve
(2) MRI scan showing a lesion in the cavernous sinus compressing the third cranial nerve
(3) Elevated inflammatory markers in blood work suggesting an underlying inflammatory process

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Steroids to reduce inflammation in the cavernous sinus
(2) Referral to a neurologist and neurosurgeon for further evaluation and potential surgical intervention
(3) Follow-up appointment in one week to reassess symptoms and discuss treatment plan in more detail
(4) Lifestyle modifications: rest, avoid strenuous activities, avoid heavy lifting/bending/straining, take regular breaks to rest eyes, consider prism glasses or patching one eye.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient began to develop numbness and weakness in the right limb 10 hours before admission, with no obvious cause. The upper limbs can be lifted, and the lower limbs need support to walk. There is no speech disorder. Symptoms persisted without headache, dizziness, or convulsions. The family then took the patient to the Department of Neurology for treatment. The head CT examination showed bilateral lacunar infarction and hospitalization was recommended. After the patient was admitted to the hospital, a brain magnetic resonance examination was performed. The patient's appetite and sleep were normal, and his bowel movements were normal.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Brain MRI
  - Acute cerebral infarction in the left basal ganglia
  - Focal stenosis of the left middle cerebral artery
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: middle cerebral artery stenosis cerebral infarction
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Have a history of hypertension
2. Main complaint is numbness and weakness of the right limb for 10 hours.
3. Physical examination revealed that the muscle strength of the right limb dropped to level 4-
4. Brain magnetic resonance examination showed acute cerebral infarction in the left basal ganglia and localized stenosis of the left middle cerebral artery.
reference_diagnosis.treatment:
After the patient was admitted to the hospital, he underwent a brain magnetic resonance examination and was diagnosed with acute cerebral infarction in the left basal ganglia. Explain the condition to the patient and family members, point out that symptoms may fluctuate and worsen, and recommend less activity and more fluids during the acute phase. Laboratory results showed triglycerides 1.99mmol/L, blood uric acid 472mmol/L, and hemoglobin 165g/L. In terms of treatment, drugs are used to improve microcirculation, protect brain tissue, and resist platelet aggregation. Specific drug treatments include:
- Xingnaojing injection 20ml, intravenous drip once a day for a total of 7 days
- Dengzhan Xixin Injection 40ml, intravenous infusion once a day for a total of 7 days
- Citicoline injection 0.5g, intravenous drip once a day for 7 days
- Shuxuetong 6ml, intravenous drip once a day for a total of 7 days
- Clopidogrel tablets 75 mg, taken orally once daily for 7 days
After treatment, the patient's symptoms were relieved, and the weakness of the right limb improved. The patient's vital signs were stable during hospitalization and met discharge standards. When discharged from the hospital, the patient was instructed to control blood pressure, continue oral medication, undergo rehabilitation, and undergo regular review.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Numbness and weakness in the right limb, constant for 10 hours
(2) Needing support to walk with the lower limbs, but able to lift upper limbs
(3) No speech disorder, headache, dizziness, or convulsions

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) MRI of spine and brain: no structural abnormalities
(2) Blood tests: slightly elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), indicating underlying inflammation or infection
(3) EMG: abnormal muscle activity in the right limb, consistent with denervation
(4) NCS: slowed nerve conduction velocities in the right limb, consistent with a demyelinating process

#Diagnosis#
Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (CIDP)

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) The patient's symptoms, particularly the numbness and weakness in the right limb, are consistent with a demyelinating disorder.
(2) The EMG and NCS results support the diagnosis of CIDP, as they indicate nerve damage and demyelination.
(3) The slightly elevated ESR suggests an underlying inflammatory process, which is also consistent with CIDP.

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG) therapy to reduce inflammation and promote nerve recovery
(2) Corticosteroids to reduce inflammation and swelling
(3) Physical therapy to improve muscle strength and mobility
(4) Regular follow-up appointments to monitor the patient's progress and adjust the treatment plan as needed

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed systemic jaundice half a month ago, accompanied by abdominal distension, oliguria, and anorexia. He received treatment in an external hospital. The treatment included antiviral, anti-infective, and albumin supplementation. However, the symptoms did not relieve. Instead, the abdominal distension worsened and edema occurred in both lower limbs. , and was therefore readmitted to the hospital. The patient reported that after the illness, he lost energy and appetite, slept normally, had dark yellow urine, small amount, dry and hard stools, and no black stools.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Color B-ultrasound:
  - The echo of the liver parenchyma is thickened, suggesting the possibility of cirrhosis.
  - Thickening of the gallbladder wall
  - accessory spleen
  - Double kidney stones
  - Ascites
- DR Chest X-ray:
  - No abnormality in cardiopulmonary diaphragm
- blood test:
  - Prothrombin time: 36.6 seconds↑
  - Troponin I: 0.02ng/ml↑
  -Alanine aminotransferase: 71.36U/L↑
  - Aspartate aminotransferase: 91.65U/L↑
  - Albumin: 40.78g/L
  - Total bilirubin: 689.03μmol/L↑
  - Direct bilirubin: 391.85μmol/L↑
  - Indirect bilirubin: 297.2umol/L↑
  - White blood cell count: 15.74×10^9/L↑
  - Neutrophil ratio: 62.5%
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Severe hepatitis
2. Chronic hepatitis B
3. Decompensated stage of hepatitis B cirrhosis
4. Acute peritonitis
5. Chronic cholecystitis
6. Double kidney stones
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. The patient has symptoms of jaundice all over the body, abdominal distension, oliguria, fatigue, anorexia and edema of both lower limbs for half a month.
2. Physical examination revealed severe jaundice of skin and mucous membranes all over the body, jaundice of the sclera, distended abdomen, mild tenderness throughout the abdomen, positive ascites sign, and moderate edema of both lower limbs.
3. The auxiliary examination results support the above diagnosis.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After the patient was admitted to the hospital, a comprehensive examination was performed and it was found that the coagulation function was poor and the patient was in critical condition. Plasma transfusion therapy was performed. If the white blood cells continue to rise, peritonitis may be considered and anti-infective treatment should be given. After admission, liver function, coagulation function, blood cell and other related tests were performed, and the results showed abnormality. After Director Zeng's ward rounds, he was diagnosed with severe hepatitis, chronic hepatitis B, hepatitis B cirrhosis, acute peritonitis, chronic cholecystitis, and kidney stones, and was given corresponding treatment. On the fifth day of hospitalization, the patient developed irritability and was considered to be in the early stage of hepatic encephalopathy. Diuretics and lactulose were added to prevent cerebral edema. After 14 days of hospitalization, the patient's symptoms showed no significant improvement, but his condition was stable and he requested to be discharged.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Jaundice all over the body
(2) Abdominal distension
(3) Oliguria
(4) Fatigue
(5) Anorexia
(6) Edema in both lower limbs

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Complete Blood Count: low hemoglobin and platelet count, elevated white blood cell count
(2) Liver Function Tests: elevated ALT, AST, ALP, and bilirubin levels
(3) Renal Function Tests: elevated BUN and creatinine levels
(4) Ultrasound of the Abdomen: moderate amount of ascites, enlarged liver with nodular texture, normal-sized kidneys
(5) Paracentesis: cloudy fluid with high protein content, pending culture results

#Diagnosis#
Liver Cirrhosis with Portal Hypertension and Spontaneous Bacterial Peritonitis (SBP)

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels indicating liver damage or dysfunction
(2) Nodular texture of the liver on ultrasound suggesting liver cirrhosis
(3) Moderate amount of ascites consistent with liver disease or portal hypertension
(4) Cloudy paracentesis fluid with high protein content indicating SBP
(5) Patient's symptoms and medical history, including previous hospitalization and treatment

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Antibiotic therapy to treat SBP
(2) Diuretics and albumin supplementation to manage ascites and edema
(3) Lactulose to reduce ammonia levels and prevent hepatic encephalopathy
(4) Vitamin K supplementation to improve coagulation
(5) Referral to a gastroenterologist or hepatologist for further evaluation and management of liver cirrhosis
(6) Close monitoring of liver function, renal function, and complete blood count to adjust treatment plan as needed

reference_diagnosis.treatment: The patient underwent relevant examinations and received treatment after admission. reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed weakness in both lower limbs without obvious triggers 20 days ago. The symptoms persisted and tended to be lighter in the morning and worse in the evening. They worsened after activity, especially when going up and down stairs or running. The patient's general condition was fair and his bowel movements were normal.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:

  - Brain magnetic resonance: no acute phase lesions.
- Neuroelectrophysiological examination

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: myasthenia gravis
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. A 31-year-old male with good health and no special medical history.
2. Recovery from a recent cold is slow and accompanied by fatigue.
3. The clinical manifestations include lightness in the morning and weightlessness in the evening, and decreased muscle strength of both lower limbs.
4. Thymus CT shows possible degeneration or hyperplasia, and facial nerve electrical examination amplitude is abnormal.
5. Serum acetylcholine receptor antibodies are positive.
reference_diagnosis.treatment:
Myasthenia gravis is diagnosed and treatment includes:
- Pyridostigmine bromide 60 mg orally three times daily for 8 days.
- Methylcobalamin injection 0.5mg, intravenous infusion once a day for 7 days.
- Vitamin B1 tablets 10mg, taken orally three times a day for 7 days.
- Sodium ganglioside injection 40 mg, intravenous infusion once a day for a total of 8 days.
- Shuxuening injection 20ml, intravenous drip once a day for a total of 8 days.
After treatment, the symptoms improved without obvious fluctuations, dyspnea or eyelid ptosis, and the discharge standards were met. After being discharged from the hospital, he was told to avoid colds, continue to take oral medications, and undergo regular check-ups.

Relapse of myasthenia gravis

(1) Patient's history of myasthenia gravis and current symptoms of muscle weakness and fatigue

(1) Adjust medication regimen to better control symptoms, potentially increasing dose or adding new medications

(3) Consider further testing, such as nerve conduction study and lumbar puncture, to rule out other conditions and confirm diagnosis

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Monitor liver function and bilirubin levels regularly
(2) Avoid triggers that can exacerbate Gilbert's syndrome, such as fasting or dehydration
(3) Consider pharmacological treatment to reduce bilirubin levels, if necessary
(4) Follow up with regular appointments to assess the effectiveness of the treatment plan and make any necessary adjustments

- Laboratory tests

Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Dizziness (lightheadedness) with a feeling of falling
(2) Double vision (diplopia)
(3) Amaurosis (blindness)
(4) Tinnitus (ringing in the ears)
(5) Headaches (mild, frequent)
(6) Blurred vision
(7) Hearing loss (gradual, left ear)
(8) Balance and coordination problems

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Physical examination: blood pressure 158/92 mmHg, pulse 72 beats per minute, reflexes normal, visual acuity slightly reduced
(2) Otoscopic examination: wax buildup in left ear canal
(3) MRI: labyrinthitis (inner ear inflammation)
(4) CT scan: cerebral vasculitis (inflammation of blood vessels in the brain), microvascular disease (small blood vessel damage)

#Diagnosis#
Labyrinthitis, cerebral vasculitis, and microvascular disease

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Symptoms of dizziness, double vision, and balance problems consistent with labyrinthitis
(2) MRI results showing inner ear inflammation
(3) CT scan results showing cerebral vasculitis and microvascular disease
(4) Patient's medical history of diabetes and hypertension contributing to microvascular disease

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Vestibular rehabilitation therapy (VRT) to improve balance and reduce dizziness
(2) Steroids and immunosuppressive medications to reduce inflammation in cerebral vasculitis
(3) Aggressive management of diabetes and hypertension through medication adjustments, diet, and exercise
(4) Regular follow-up appointments to monitor progress and adjust treatment plan as needed

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Heart palpitations for more than 6 years, worsened over the past 10 months
(2) Rapid heartbeats, sometimes feeling like the heart is skipping beats
(3) Chest tightness, usually accompanying the palpitations
(4) Stress and anxiety, trouble sleeping

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Electrocardiogram (ECG): normal sinus rhythm, no signs of atrial fibrillation or other abnormal heart rhythms
(2) Holter monitor test: occasional premature ventricular contractions (PVCs) and premature atrial contractions (PACs), episodes of tachycardia during stress or anxiety
(3) Echocardiogram: normal heart structure and function, no signs of mitral valve prolapse or other structural abnormalities
(4) Stress test: normal heart rate and blood pressure response to physical activity, but increased heart rate and blood pressure during the test, indicative of an anxiety-related condition

#Diagnosis#
Anxiety disorder, specifically anxiety-induced palpitations

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Patient's symptoms of heart palpitations, chest tightness, and stress/anxiety
(2) Results of auxiliary examinations, including ECG, Holter monitor test, echocardiogram, and stress test, which ruled out underlying cardiac conditions and suggested an anxiety-related condition

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Medication to manage anxiety and reduce symptoms
(2) Referral to a cardiologist for further evaluation and management
(3) Recommendation to practice stress-reducing techniques, such as meditation, deep breathing, or yoga, to help manage anxiety and stress levels

After potassium supplementation, the blood potassium was rechecked at 1.3mmol/L. The blood gas analysis was rechecked again and showed K+1.7mmol/L. The central venous pump was used. After potassium removal, recheck blood gas analysis showed K+7.2mmol/L, and recheck K+3.39mmol/L after treatment. The symptoms gradually improved, and he was admitted to our department for "hypokalemic periodic paralysis?"

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Secondary hypokalemic periodic paralysis: primary hyperthyroidism Graves' disease
2. Cystic thyroid nodules
reference_diagnosis.basis: The patient had repeated fatigue and paralysis. On physical examination, he had grade II thyroid enlargement, soft texture, and audible vascular murmur. Combined with hypokalemia, the diagnosis of hypokalemic periodic paralysis was basically clear. Considering that it may be caused by primary hyperthyroidism, it is recommended to further check 3 items of thyroid function, TR-Ab and thyroid B-ultrasound to confirm the diagnosis.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, relevant examinations were completed, and treatment was given with absolute bed rest, oxygen inhalation, and a high-quality protein diet. Intravenous potassium supplementation and oral potassium chloride granules were administered. Medications for the primary disease: methimazole, selenium yeast, vitamin B1 complex tablets, propranolol. After 7 days of treatment, the electrolytes were normal, paralysis did not recur, the heart rate was normal, fatigue was relieved, and vital signs were stable. The patient was discharged from the hospital with medication, and was instructed to continue taking antithyroid drugs, take oral potassium supplements, eat a low-iodine, high-calorie diet, exercise appropriately, and avoid cold and fatigue. Regularly review electrolytes, blood routine, liver and kidney function, and thyroid function, and adjust the medication plan. Cystic thyroid nodules are most likely to be benign, so they should be observed temporarily and have regular color ultrasound examinations.

#Symptoms#
(1) Recurrent fatigue
(2) Flaccid paralysis
(3) Polyphagia

(5) Irritability

(7) Muscle weakness
(8) Frequent urination
(9) Loose bowel movements

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) EMG: Abnormal muscle activity, denervation, and reinnervation
(2) Thyroid function test: Elevated TSH, decreased FT4 and FT3 (hypothyroidism)
(3) Nerve conduction study: Slowed nerve conduction velocities and prolonged distal latencies (demyelinating peripheral neuropathy)
(4) Muscle biopsy: Neurogenic atrophy, small angular fibers, and fiber type grouping
(5) Blood tests: Elevated anti-GQ1b antibodies (Miller Fisher syndrome), elevated thyroid peroxidase antibodies (autoimmune hypothyroidism)

#Diagnosis#
Miller Fisher syndrome (a variant of Guillain-Barré syndrome) and autoimmune hypothyroidism

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Clinical symptoms: Recurrent fatigue, flaccid paralysis, and muscle weakness
(2) EMG and nerve conduction study results: Consistent with demyelinating peripheral neuropathy
(3) Blood tests: Elevated anti-GQ1b antibodies and thyroid peroxidase antibodies
(4) Muscle biopsy: Neurogenic atrophy and fiber type grouping

#Treatment Plan#
(1) IVIG therapy to reduce inflammation and modulate the immune system
(2) Thyroid hormone replacement therapy to normalize thyroid hormone levels
(3) Lifestyle changes: Rest, stress management, balanced diet, and gradual exercise program
(4) Close monitoring of progress and adjustment of treatment plan as needed

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient went to the emergency department of our hospital six months ago due to dizziness. His blood pressure was measured at 192/123mmHg. When he visited the emergency department again, his blood pressure was 200/122mmHg, and CTA of the thoracoabdominal aorta showed no abnormalities. After treatment, his blood pressure was still high and he was hospitalized for further diagnosis and treatment. The patient had a good spirit and appetite, snored at night, occasionally had apnea, and had no obvious weight change.

reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure was >140/90 mmHg at rest for many times, reaching the diagnostic criteria for hypertension. The cause is unknown and further examination is required.
2. Obstructive sleep apnea hypopnea syndrome? : The patient is obese, snoring at night, accompanied by apnea, combined with extremely high blood pressure and hypoxemia, considering whether this syndrome exists.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After the patient was admitted to the hospital, he was given oxygen inhalation and sodium bicarbonate fluid infusion according to the results of blood gas analysis. Sodium nitroprusside was used for antihypertensive treatment. Further examinations included blood lipids, liver function, thyroid function, etc. After consultation with the otolaryngology department, he was diagnosed with severe sleep apnea-hypopnea syndrome and nocturnal hypoxemia. Atorvastatin calcium was given to regulate blood lipids, nasal positive pressure ventilation therapy to improve apnea, and antihypertensive drugs. After 7 days of treatment, the patient's symptoms improved, blood pressure was 147/92 mmHg, and he was discharged from the hospital.

Helicobacter pylori infection was eradicated with quadruple therapy. After treatment, the melena stopped, the hemoglobin concentration rebounded, the symptoms were relieved, and the patient was discharged.

(3) Stool test: Positive for occult blood

#Diagnosis#
Gastric ulcer

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Endoscopy results showing a gastric ulcer and inflammation in the stomach lining
(2) CBC results indicating mild anemia due to chronic bleeding
(3) Stool test results confirming occult blood in the stool
(4) Patient's symptoms and medical history, including frequent use of acetaminophen and history of duodenal ulcer

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Prescribe proton pump inhibitor (PPI) to reduce acid production and help the ulcer heal
(2) Prescribe antibiotic to treat underlying Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection
(3) Stop taking acetaminophen and switch to a different pain reliever
(4) Make lifestyle changes, including eating smaller, more frequent meals, avoiding spicy or fatty foods, and managing stress levels
(5) Schedule follow-up appointment in 4-6 weeks to monitor progress and perform another endoscopy
(6) Prescribe iron supplements to address mild anemia

Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Chest tightness and pressure sensation
(2) Dry and non-productive cough
(3) Shortness of breath, especially when lying down or exerting oneself
(4) Yellowish discoloration of eyes and skin
(5) Yellow urine
(6) Fatigue
(7) Poor appetite
(8) Abdominal discomfort in the upper right quadrant
(9) Pale and clay-colored stools
(10) Nausea, especially in the morning, and worsened by fatty or greasy foods

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Complete Blood Count (CBC): elevated white blood cell count
(2) Liver Function Tests (LFTs): elevated alanine transaminase (ALT) and aspartate transaminase (AST) levels, and elevated alkaline phosphatase (ALP) level
(3) Bilirubin level: high
(4) Ultrasound of liver and gallbladder: enlarged liver, fatty liver disease, and suspicion of gallstones
(5) Viral hepatitis panel: pending
(6) Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP): pending

#Diagnosis#
Alcoholic liver disease with possible gallstone disease and bile duct obstruction

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Patient's history of heavy alcohol consumption
(2) Symptoms of jaundice, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort
(3) Elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels
(4) Ultrasound findings of fatty liver disease and suspected gallstones
(5) Pending results of viral hepatitis panel and ERCP to rule out other potential causes

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Immediate cessation of alcohol consumption
(2) Medications to manage symptoms and support liver function, such as ursodiol, antihistamines, and vitamin supplements
(3) Follow-up appointments with regular blood tests to monitor liver function and bilirubin levels
(4) ERCP procedure to visualize bile ducts and pancreatic ducts, and to remove any blockages or stones
(5) Possible surgical intervention if ERCP is unsuccessful or if there are complications
(6) Lifestyle modifications, including a healthy diet and regular exercise, to support liver health and overall well-being

Echocardiography showed an ejection fraction (EF) of 38%, pericardial effusion (a small amount) and reduced left ventricular systolic function. The symptoms were relieved after treatment with vasodilator drugs. In the past three days, the symptoms have worsened again, accompanied by waking up at night. The patient reported a decrease in the quality of his diet and sleep, a decrease in urine output, a weight loss of about 10 pounds, and normal stools.

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis: Dilated cardiomyopathy, chronic heart failure, cardiac function class III, coronary atherosclerosis, and post-coronary angiography.
reference_diagnosis.basis: The patient had typical symptoms of heart failure such as chest tightness and shortness of breath. The cardiac ultrasound showed that the heart was enlarged, the ejection fraction was reduced, and NT-ProBNP was elevated. Based on the clinical manifestations and auxiliary examination results, the patient was diagnosed as chronic heart failure, and the cardiac function was divided according to the severity of the symptoms. Level III.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After the patient was admitted to the hospital, he was given anti-heart failure and prognosis-improving drug treatment for chest tightness, shortness of breath and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea. Considering decompensation of acute heart failure, diuretic therapy with furosemide and spironolactone was administered, and recombinant human natriuretic peptide was used to reduce cardiac load. The addition of dapagliflozin and betaloc improved cardiac function. After treatment, the patient's symptoms were relieved, and the NT-ProBNP dropped to 550.9 pg/ml during reexamination. Coronary angiography showed mild stenosis, and heart failure was considered to be caused by dilated cardiomyopathy.

(1) Electrocardiogram (ECG): abnormal heart rhythms, including prolonged QT interval and ST-segment depression
(2) Chest X-ray: fluid accumulation in the lungs
(3) Blood tests: elevated troponin levels, elevated B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels, and signs of anemia

#Diagnosis#
Heart failure with possible recent heart attack or heart damage

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Patient's symptoms, including chest tightness, shortness of breath, and palpitations
(2) Abnormal ECG and chest X-ray results
(3) Elevated troponin and BNP levels, indicating heart damage and heart failure
(4) Patient's medical history, including previous episode of heart-related symptoms

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Hospital admission for further treatment and monitoring
(2) Medication adjustment to manage heart failure and reduce fluid accumulation in the lungs
(3) Oxygen therapy to help with shortness of breath
(4) Echocardiogram to assess heart function and check for further damage
(5) Lifestyle changes, including stress reduction, regular exercise, heart-healthy diet, and quitting smoking (if applicable)

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient began to experience palpitation without obvious triggers 2 years ago. He was treated in another hospital and diagnosed with atrial fibrillation and atrial fibrillation. His symptoms improved after treatment. After that, the patient took propafenone intermittently, and her palpitation symptoms were relieved. Six days ago, the patient developed shortness of breath again and was unable to lie down. He went to a local hospital and was diagnosed with heart failure. He was subsequently transferred to the emergency department of our hospital. The patient denied symptoms such as blurred vision, fever and chills, cough and sputum, nausea and vomiting, abdominal pain and diarrhea, frequent urination, urgent urination and painful urination, edema of both lower limbs, and nighttime awakening. Her diet and sleep are normal, her mental and physical strength are good, her bowel movements are normal, and her weight has not changed significantly recently.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Blood biochemistry:
  -NT-ProBNP: 1064.00 pg/mL
  - cTnI: 0.053 ng/mL
- Echocardiography:
  - EF (Ejection Fraction): 40%
  - Segmental thinning of left ventricular myocardium and abnormal movement
  - Enlargement of the left heart and myocardial hypertrophy of the remaining segments of the left ventricle
  - Trend of left ventricular apical aneurysm formation
  - Reduced left ventricular systolic function
- Holter ECG:
  - Ectopic rhythm, atrial fibrillation with long pauses, maximum R-R interval 2.25 seconds
  - Ventricular escape beats, frequent premature ventricular beats from multiple sources, paired premature ventricular beats, premature ventricular beats, doublet and triplet rhythm
  - Short bursts of ventricular tachycardia
  - ST segment changes
  - Sustained abnormal Q waves in leads IIIIIAVF, v3-v6
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy accompanied by myocardial insufficiency, cardiac insufficiency grade III
2. Arrhythmia: persistent atrial fibrillation, frequent premature ventricular contractions, short bursts of ventricular tachycardia
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. The patient has episodic shortness of breath and cannot lie down. Echocardiography shows an enlarged left heart and reduced systolic function. He has no other underlying diseases. He is diagnosed with dilated cardiomyopathy and his heart function is classified as level III.
2. Dynamic electrocardiogram shows atrial fibrillation rhythm, frequent premature ventricular contractions, and short bursts of ventricular tachycardia.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: The patient was given oral aspirin, clopidogrel, atorvastatin, and metoprolol succinate because of abnormal Q waves on the electrocardiogram and a tendency to form apical aneurysms. Coronary angiography showed no stenosis, and left ventricular angiography showed a slightly enlarged left ventricle and weakened apical motion. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging showed a high possibility of left ventricular hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, so dual antiplatelet therapy was discontinued and rivaroxaban was added to prevent thrombosis. Five days later, the shortness of breath symptoms were relieved and the patient was discharged from the hospital.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Nausea and vomiting
(2) Scleral jaundice and yellow urine
(3) Upper abdominal pain (paroxysmal, dull, and located under the xiphoid process and on the upper right side of the abdomen)
(4) Loss of appetite
(5) Abnormal bowel movements (hard stools)

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Complete Blood Count (CBC): elevated liver enzymes
(2) Liver Function Tests (LFTs): elevated bilirubin levels
(3) Ultrasound of the Abdomen: dilated common bile duct (CBD) and slightly enlarged liver

#Diagnosis#
Cholelithiasis (gallstones) with possible obstruction of the common bile duct

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels indicating liver dysfunction and jaundice
(2) Ultrasound findings of a dilated common bile duct and slightly enlarged liver suggesting obstruction or blockage in the bile ducts
(3) Patient's symptoms of upper abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting consistent with gallstone disease

#Treatment Plan#
(1) ERCP (endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography) to visualize the bile ducts and pancreatic ducts and potentially remove any gallstones
(2) CT scan to rule out other possible causes of symptoms, such as pancreatic cancer or cholangiocarcinoma
(3) Medication to manage symptoms of nausea and vomiting, and to reduce bilirubin levels
(4) Dietary changes to avoid fatty or greasy foods and stick to a bland diet
(5) Further treatment will depend on the results of the ERCP and CT scan, and may include surgical removal of the gallbladder or other interventions.

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient developed fever without obvious triggers 1 week ago, with a maximum body temperature of 38°C, accompanied by cough, yellow sticky sputum, and sore throat. There was no chest pain, chest tightness, shortness of breath and other symptoms. There was no nausea or vomiting, no abdominal pain, bloating, and no frequent urination. Urinary urgency, painful urination, no twitching of the limbs, and no change in consciousness. See a doctor for further diagnosis and treatment.

reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Pulmonary fungal infection
2. Decompensated stage of cirrhosis after hepatitis B
3. Liver cyst
reference_diagnosis.basis:
1. A 49-year-old male had a fever with cough and sputum for 3 days. He had a history of hepatitis B cirrhosis and esophageal varices and was receiving antiviral treatment.
2. Physical examination revealed pharyngeal congestion, slightly coarse breath sounds in both lungs, a few moist rales, and no obvious abnormalities in the heart and abdomen.
3. Auxiliary examinations showed cirrhosis sonography, liver cysts, and splenomegaly.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: The patient underwent a comprehensive examination after admission, including blood routine, biochemistry, chest CT, three pairs of hepatitis B, urine routine, stool routine, etc. Based on the examination results and the patient's symptoms and signs, the patient was diagnosed with pulmonary infection, decompensated cirrhosis after hepatitis B, and liver cysts. For treatment, cefotaxime sodium and sulbactam sodium were given as anti-infective treatment, compound pholcodine oral liquid and Suhuang Zhike capsule were used to eliminate phlegm and relieve cough. Subsequent antifungal treatment with itraconazole, polyene phosphatidylcholine and Kangai injection were added to treat liver cirrhosis. Hypoalbuminemia is treated with albumin infusion. After 13 days of treatment, the patient's symptoms were relieved.

(4) Sputum culture to determine the type of bacteria causing pneumonia

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Chest tightness and shortness of breath for 3 years, worsening over the past 2 months
(2) Fatigue, coughing, and yellow phlegm
(3) Swelling in both legs, worse at the end of the day
(4) Decreased urine output and darker urine color

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Chest X-ray: fluid buildup in the lungs
(2) ECG: abnormal heart rhythms
(3) CBC: slight increase in white blood cells
(4) Echocardiogram: decreased ejection fraction, indicating worsening heart failure
(5) Blood culture: negative, ruling out underlying infection

#Diagnosis#
Worsening heart failure

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Patient's symptoms, including chest tightness, shortness of breath, fatigue, and swelling in the legs
(2) Results of auxiliary examinations, including chest X-ray, ECG, CBC, echocardiogram, and blood culture
(3) Patient's medical history, including hypertension and heart failure diagnosis 3 years ago

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Increase dosage of heart failure medications, including Nostal, Furosemide, and Spironolactone
(2) Implement a fluid restriction plan to reduce fluid buildup in the lungs and other parts of the body
(3) Encourage a low-sodium diet to reduce fluid retention and blood pressure
(4) Consider adding additional medications, such as beta-blockers or ACE inhibitors, to help manage heart failure and reduce symptoms
(5) Schedule a follow-up appointment in 2 weeks to reassess symptoms and adjust treatment plan as needed

In the past two days, her cough worsened, accompanied by sputum production, fever (maximum body temperature 39°C), shortness of breath, and dyspnea. She was treated in a local hospital. Chest CT showed severe infection of both lungs, and she was transferred to the emergency department of our hospital. Recently, my energy, diet, and sleep have been poor, and my weight loss is unknown.

2. Septic septic shock
3. Type I respiratory failure
4. Left heart failure combined with acute pulmonary edema
5. Cirrhosis of the liver
6. Acute-on-chronic liver failure
7. Type 2 diabetes
reference_diagnosis.basis: The patient was admitted to the hospital due to long-term cough, fever, and dyspnea. Physical examination revealed severe jaundice, spider nevi, moist rales, etc. Auxiliary examinations showed hypoxemia, acidosis, elevated white blood cells, and significantly elevated CRP. Combined with chest CT results, the diagnosis of severe pneumonia was supported. The patient had a history of cirrhosis and diabetes, and had abnormal liver function, which was consistent with the diagnosis of acute-on-chronic liver failure.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient underwent a comprehensive examination and emergency treatment, including anti-infection, anti-inflammation, organ protection, nutritional support, etc. After active treatment, the patient's condition gradually improved, the infection was controlled, his liver function improved, and he was eventually discharged from the hospital.

#Symptoms#
(1) Recurrent cough for more than 5 months, worsening with fever and dyspnea for the past 2 days

(3) Chest tightness, especially when coughing or taking a deep breath
(4) Decreased appetite, fatigue, and weight loss
(5) History of liver cirrhosis and type 2 diabetes

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Chest X-ray: Consolidation in the right lower lobe of the lung, consistent with pneumonia
(2) Complete Blood Count (CBC): Elevated white blood cell count, indicating infection, and slightly low hemoglobin level
(3) Blood Sugar Level Tests: Elevated blood sugar levels
(4) Liver Function Tests: Elevated liver enzymes, indicating liver damage
(5) Sputum Culture: Grew Streptococcus pneumoniae, a type of bacteria that can cause pneumonia

#Diagnosis#
Pneumonia caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Chest X-ray showing consolidation in the right lower lobe of the lung
(2) Elevated white blood cell count and slightly low hemoglobin level on CBC
(3) Elevated blood sugar levels and liver enzymes indicating underlying diabetes and liver cirrhosis
(4) Sputum culture growing Streptococcus pneumoniae
(5) Patient's symptoms and medical history

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Antibiotics to treat the pneumonia
(2) Respiratory support with oxygen therapy
(3) Diabetes management to control blood sugar levels
(4) Liver support and monitoring of liver enzymes
(5) Pain management for chest tightness and discomfort
(6) Rest and hydration to aid in recovery

reference_diagnosis.symptom: The patient ate a high-fat diet after dinner on January 23, 2022, and felt upper abdominal pain from 9 a.m. the next day. The pain was concentrated in the left upper abdomen, persistent and severe, accompanied by nausea and vomiting, and vomiting did not relieve the pain. There was no radiating pain in the left lower back, acid reflux, heartburn, hematemesis, melena, or fever, chills, or jaundice. No treatment was given, and he came to the emergency room because his symptoms worsened. CT examination on admission showed pancreatitis with peripheral effusion and fatty liver. The patient had no dizziness, fatigue, palpitation, chest tightness, chest pain, shortness of breath, cough, or expectoration. He had normal urine, no flatulence and defecation, and no significant change in weight.
reference_diagnosis.medical_test:
- Blood routine: WBC count 15.14x10^9/L
- Electrolytes: basically normal
- Blood lipids: Triglycerides 9.44mmol/L
- Liver and kidney function: normal
- Procalcitonin: normal
- Blood sugar: normal
- Imaging: Upper abdominal CT showed pancreatitis with peripheral exudation and fatty liver
reference_diagnosis.diagnosis:
1. Acute pancreatitis hyperlipidemia type
2. Systemic inflammatory response syndrome
3. Fatty liver
4. Hyperlipidemia
5. Hypoalbuminemia
reference_diagnosis.basis: The patient was admitted to the hospital due to upper abdominal distension and pain for 7 hours. The medical history, symptoms, physical examination and auxiliary examination results (especially upper abdominal CT and white blood cell count) supported the diagnosis of acute pancreatitis and fatty liver.
reference_diagnosis.treatment: After admission, the patient's abdominal pain worsened and he developed high fever, up to 39°C. ECG, blood pressure, and blood oxygen monitoring were performed, and low-flow oxygen inhalation was performed. Omeprazole was used to suppress acid, low molecular weight heparin was used to lower lipids, somatostatin was used to suppress pancreatic enzyme secretion, fluids were replenished to maintain water and electrolyte balance, and moxifloxacin was used for anti-infection treatment. The patient recovered and was discharged from the hospital on January 30, 2022. When discharged, she had no fever, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, or abdominal distension, and had normal gas and bowel movements.

doctor_diagnosis.diagnosis:
Here is the summary:

#Symptoms#
(1) Upper abdominal distension and pain for 7 hours, started after a high-fat diet
(2) Nausea and vomiting, no relief after vomiting
(3) Pain is persistent, severe, and dull, located in the left upper abdomen

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) CT scan: pancreatitis with peripheral effusion and fatty liver
(2) Abdominal palpation: tenderness and guarding in the left upper quadrant, especially in the epigastric region
(3) Complete Blood Count (CBC): slightly elevated White Blood Cell Count (WBC)
(4) Comprehensive Metabolic Panel (CMP): slightly elevated Alkaline Phosphatase (ALP)
(5) Lipase and Amylase Test: elevated lipase and amylase levels
(6) Ultrasound of the Abdomen: enlarged pancreas with heterogeneous echotexture, consistent with pancreatitis

#Diagnosis#
Acute Pancreatitis

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Clinical symptoms: upper abdominal distension and pain, nausea and vomiting
(2) Imaging studies: CT scan and ultrasound of the abdomen showing pancreatitis
(3) Laboratory tests: elevated lipase and amylase levels, slightly elevated WBC and ALP

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Hospitalization for further care and monitoring
(2) Pain management with medication
(3) Anti-nausea medication to manage vomiting
(4) Antibiotics to prevent infection
(5) Low-fat diet to reduce strain on the pancreas
(6) Pancreatic enzyme supplements to aid digestion

There was no abdominal distension, diarrhea, chest tightness, shortness of breath, fever or chest pain. There was no severe nausea or vomiting before the onset of symptoms. #Symptoms#
(1) Black stools intermittently for 6 days
(2) Dizziness, palpitations, and fatigue

(4) Discomfort after eating sometimes

#Auxiliary Examinations#
(1) Complete Blood Count (CBC): mild anemia
(2) Stool test: occult blood in stool
(3) Endoscopy: gastric ulcer in the stomach, bleeding slightly, caused by Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection

#Diagnosis#
Gastric ulcer caused by Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) infection

#Diagnostic Basis#
(1) Endoscopy results showing gastric ulcer and H. pylori infection
(2) Stool test results showing occult blood in stool
(3) CBC results showing mild anemia

#Treatment Plan#
(1) Antibiotics to treat H. pylori infection
(2) Medications to reduce acid production in the stomach and help the ulcer heal
(3) Antacids or acid reducers to neutralize stomach acid and reduce discomfort
(4) Medication to protect the stomach lining and promote healing
(5) Lifestyle changes: avoid spicy or fatty foods, eat smaller, more frequent meals, avoid smoking and alcohol
(6) Follow-up appointments: 2 weeks and 6 weeks after initial treatment to monitor progress and confirm healing.
